Davis Station is located at 68°35′S77°58′E﻿ / ﻿68.583°S 77.967°E on the coast of Cooperation Sea in Princess Elizabeth Land (Ingrid Christensen Coast) in a remarkable ice free area (Antarctic oasis) of [MASK] known as the Vestfold Hills.
Lake Jabs is a small lake next east of Club Lake in the central part of Breidnes Peninsula, Vestfold Hills, [MASK].

Walkabout Rocks is a prominent rock exposure along the coast at the north-eastern extremity of the Vestfold Hills, about 0.5 nautical miles (0.9 km; 0.6 mi) south of the Wyatt Earp Islands of Princess Elizabeth Land, [MASK].

Davis Anchorage (68°34′S77°55′E﻿ / ﻿68.567°S 77.917°E) is an anchorage in [MASK] about 1 nautical mile (2 km) in extent with general depths of 10 to 13 fathoms (18 to 24 m), lying off Breidnes Peninsula, Vestfold Hills.

Mule Island (68°39′S77°50′E﻿ / ﻿68.650°S 77.833°E) is a small island lying immediately southwest of Hawker Island, off the west tip of Mule Peninsula, Vestfold Hills, in Prydz Bay, [MASK].
Ellis Fjord (68°36′S78°5′E﻿ / ﻿68.600°S 78.083°E) is a long narrow fjord between Breidnes Peninsula and Mule Peninsula in the Vestfold Hills of [MASK].
Flutter Island is an irregular-shaped island, almost cut in two, lying in Prydz Bay between Trigwell Island and Breidnes Peninsula, near the Vestfold Hills of [MASK].
Lucas Island is a small island lying just west of the Vestfold Hills, [MASK], 4 kilometres (2 nmi) northwest of Plog Island.

Heidemann Bay (68°35′S77°58′E﻿ / ﻿68.583°S 77.967°E) is a bay, 1 nautical mile (2 km) long, indenting the seaward end of Breidnes Peninsula in the Vestfold Hills of [MASK], just south of Davis Station.

Lugg Island is a small island lying 2 kilometres (1 nmi) northwest of Lake Island, off the west end of Breidnes Peninsula, Vestfold Hills, [MASK].

Kenfield Nunatak (73°46′S99°3′W﻿ / ﻿73.767°S 99.050°W) is an isolated nunatak which lies about 8 nautical miles (15 km) southeast of the head of Cosgrove Ice Shelf and 17 nautical miles (31 km) east-northeast of Pryor Cliff, at the extreme northern end of the Hudson Mountains, [MASK].
The Hudson Mountains is a group of parasitic cones, forming nunataks just above the [MASK] ice sheet in west Ellsworth Land.

Wright Peninsula (67°28′S68°10′W﻿ / ﻿67.467°S 68.167°W) is a peninsula lying between Ryder Bay and Stonehouse Bay on the east coast of Adelaide Island, [MASK].

Webb Island (67°27′S67°56′W﻿ / ﻿67.450°S 67.933°W) is a rocky island in [MASK], 1.5 nautical miles (2.8 km) long, lying in Laubeuf Fjord about 3 nautical miles (6 km) south of the entrance to Stonehouse Bay, close to Adelaide Island.
Stonehouse Bay (67°21′S68°5′W﻿ / ﻿67.350°S 68.083°W) is a bay in [MASK] on the west side of Laubeuf Fjord, indenting the east coast of Adelaide Island between Hunt Peak and Sighing Peak.
Stonehouse Bay (67°21′S68°5′W﻿ / ﻿67.350°S 68.083°W) is a bay in [MASK] on the west side of Laubeuf Fjord, indenting the east coast of Adelaide Island between Hunt Peak and Sighing Peak.

Hunt Peak (67°18′S68°2′W﻿ / ﻿67.300°S 68.033°W) is a triangular rock peak, 610 metres (2,000 ft) high, marking the north side of the entrance to Stonehouse Bay on the east coast of Adelaide Island, [MASK].

McCallum Pass (67°23′S68°18′W﻿ / ﻿67.383°S 68.300°W) is a pass between the northeast ridge of Mount Mangin and the ridge on the south side of Stonehouse Bay, in the southern part of Adelaide Island, [MASK].

Elemag Point (Nos Elemag 'nos 'e-le-mag) is a point on the coast of Moon Bay in Livingston Island, [MASK] situated 6.75 km south-southwest of Edinburgh Hill, 1.76 km southeast of Sindel Point, 3.05 km east of Sliven Peak, 2.05 km northeast of Zlatograd Rock, and 5,57 km northwest of Rila Point.

Moon Bay is a bay 7 nautical miles (13 km) wide which recedes 4 nautical miles (7 km) between Edinburgh Hill and Renier Point, on the east side of Livingston Island, in the South Shetland Islands off [MASK].

Sindel Point (Bulgarian: нос Синдел, ‘Nos Sindel’ 'nos 'sin-del) is a low ice-free point on the east coast of Livingston Island in the South Shetland Islands, [MASK] projecting 250 m into Moon Bay to separate the glacier termini of Kaliakra Glacier to the north and Struma Glacier to the south.
Bruix Cove is the 1.93 km wide cove indenting for 1.75 km the south coast of Moon Bay in eastern Livingston Island, the South Shetland Islands in [MASK].

Edinburgh Hill is a narrow point projecting 650 m from the east coast of Varna Peninsula, Livingston Island in the South Shetland Islands, [MASK] into McFarlane Strait and ending up in a conspicuous rocky hill of elevation 180 m. The point forms the northwest side of the entrance to Moon Bay.

Rila Point (Nos Rila 'nos 'ri-la) is a low, ice-free point on the south coast of Moon Bay, projecting 330 m west-northwestwards from Burgas Peninsula on Livingston Island in the South Shetland Islands, [MASK], and forming the east side of the entrance to Bruix Cove.

Mount Calais (69°11′S70°15′W﻿ / ﻿69.183°S 70.250°W) is a massive mountain, 2,345 metres (7,700 ft) high, at the northwest side of Schokalsky Bay in the northeast part of Alexander Island, [MASK].

Walter Glacier (69°17′S70°21′W﻿ / ﻿69.283°S 70.350°W) is a glacier flowing east-northeast, merging with the south side of Moran Glacier to enter Schokalsky Bay, situated in the northeast portion of Alexander Island, [MASK].
Mount Hahn is a mountain, about 1,100 metres (3,600 ft) high, situated between Walter Glacier and Hampton Glacier at the head of Schokalsky Bay, in northeastern Alexander Island, [MASK].

Moran Glacier (69°14′S70°16′W﻿ / ﻿69.233°S 70.267°W) is a glacier 10 nautical miles (18 km) long, joined at the south side by Walter Glacier, flowing east into Schokalsky Bay, situated in the northeast portion of Alexander Island, [MASK].

Schokalsky Bay (69°15′S69°55′W﻿ / ﻿69.250°S 69.917°W) is the easternmost bay of Alexander Island, [MASK], 9 nautical miles (17 km) wide at its entrance and indenting 6 nautical miles (11 km) lying between Mount Calais and Cape Brown along the east coast of Alexander Island whilst adjacent to the George VI Ice Shelf in George VI Sound.

Schokalsky Bay (69°15′S69°55′W﻿ / ﻿69.250°S 69.917°W) is the easternmost bay of Alexander Island, [MASK], 9 nautical miles (17 km) wide at its entrance and indenting 6 nautical miles (11 km) lying between Mount Calais and Cape Brown along the east coast of Alexander Island whilst adjacent to the George VI Ice Shelf in George VI Sound.
Burton Point (66°16′S66°56′W﻿ / ﻿66.267°S 66.933°W) is the northeastern point of Krogh Island in the Biscoe Islands, [MASK] forming the north side of the northeast entrance to Vladigerov Passage.
Krogh Island (66°17′S67°0′W﻿ / ﻿66.283°S 67.000°W) is an ice-covered island about 5 nautical miles (9 km) long lying close west of the southern part of Lavoisier Island in Biscoe Islands, [MASK].
Krogh Island (66°17′S67°0′W﻿ / ﻿66.283°S 67.000°W) is an ice-covered island about 5 nautical miles (9 km) long lying close west of the southern part of Lavoisier Island in Biscoe Islands, [MASK].
Edholm Point (66°15′S67°4′W﻿ / ﻿66.250°S 67.067°W) is the northwestern point of Krogh Island in the Biscoe Islands, [MASK] forming the west side of the entrance to Transmarisca Bay.

Lewis Sound (66°20′S67°0′W﻿ / ﻿66.333°S 67.000°W) is a body of water running northwest–southeast between Lavoisier Island and Krogh Island to the northeast and Watkins Island to the southwest, in the Biscoe Islands of [MASK].
Transmarisca Bay (Bulgarian: залив Трансмариска, ‘Zaliv Transmarisca’ 'za-liv trans-ma-'ri-ska) is the 4.3 km wide bay indenting for 3.2 km the north coast of Krogh Island in Biscoe Islands, [MASK].
Zagrade Point (Bulgarian: нос Заграде, ‘Nos Zagrade’ 'nos za-'gra-de) is the point on the east side of the entrance to Suregetes Cove on the north coast of Krogh Island in Biscoe Islands, [MASK].

Kuvikal Point (Bulgarian: нос Кувикъл, ‘Nos Kuvikal’ 'nos 'ku-vi-k&l) is the point on the east side of the entrance to Transmarisca Bay and the west side of the entrance to Suregetes Cove on the north coast of Krogh Island in Biscoe Islands, [MASK].

Vladigerov Passage (Bulgarian: Владигеров проток, ‘Vladigerov Protok’ vla-di-'ge-rov 'pro-tok) is the passage long 5.8 km in southwest-northeast direction and 1.05 km wide in Biscoe Islands, [MASK] between Lavoisier Island on the east and Krogh Island on the west.
Suregetes Cove (Bulgarian: залив Сурегетес, ‘Zaliv Suregetes’ 'za-liv su-re-'ge-tes) is the 2.47 km wide cove indenting for 1.9 km the N coast of Krogh Island in Biscoe Islands, [MASK].

Bachstrom Point (65°29′S63°51′W﻿ / ﻿65.483°S 63.850°W) is a headland on the northeast side of Beascochea Bay, 8 nautical miles (15 km) southeast of Cape Perez on the southwest coast of Kiev Peninsula in Graham Land, [MASK].

Beascochea Bay (65°30′S64°0′W﻿ / ﻿65.500°S 64.000°W) is a bay, 10 nautical miles (19 km) long and 5 nautical miles (9 km) wide, indenting the Graham Coast of Graham Land, [MASK], between Kiev Peninsula and Barison Peninsula, and entered south of Cape Perez.

Beascochea Bay (65°30′S64°0′W﻿ / ﻿65.500°S 64.000°W) is a bay, 10 nautical miles (19 km) long and 5 nautical miles (9 km) wide, indenting the Graham Coast of Graham Land, [MASK], between Kiev Peninsula and Barison Peninsula, and entered south of Cape Perez.

Cadman Glacier (65°37′S63°47′W﻿ / ﻿65.617°S 63.783°W) is a glacier, 1.5 nautical miles (3 km) wide at its mouth and about 7 nautical miles (13 km) long, flowing northwestward into the head of the southern arm of Beascochea Bay south of Plas Point on the west side of the [MASK] Peninsula.

The Kramer Rocks (65°26′S64°2′W﻿ / ﻿65.433°S 64.033°W) are two rocks lying in the northern part of Beascochea Bay, 3 nautical miles (10 km) southeast of Cape Perez on the west coast of Graham Land, [MASK].
Funk Glacier (65°34′S63°46′W﻿ / ﻿65.567°S 63.767°W) is a glacier flowing into the head of Nevsha Cove in Beascochea Bay to the south of Frölich Peak, on the west coast of Graham Land, [MASK].

Frölich Peak (65°32′S63°48′W﻿ / ﻿65.533°S 63.800°W) is a peak 1,035 metres (3,400 ft) high, rising above Holst Point and dominating Chorul Peninsula at the head of Beascochea Bay on the west coast of Graham Land, [MASK].

McCollum Peak (65°32′S64°2′W﻿ / ﻿65.533°S 64.033°W) is a peak, 735 metres (2,410 ft) high, standing south of Beascochea Bay 2 nautical miles (4 km) southeast of Mount Waugh, on the west coast of Graham Land, [MASK].
Holst Point (65°32′S63°50′W﻿ / ﻿65.533°S 63.833°W) is a point at the head of Beascochea Bay which divides it into two arms, on the west coast of Graham Land, [MASK].

Lever Glacier (65°30′S63°40′W﻿ / ﻿65.500°S 63.667°W) is a glacier, 1.5 nautical miles (3 km) wide at its mouth and at least 6 nautical miles (11 km) long, flowing west-northwest, then west-southwest into the head of the northern arm of Beascochea Bay north of Chorul Peninsula, on the west coast of Graham Land, [MASK].

Chorul Peninsula (Bulgarian: полуостров Чорул, ‘Poluostrov Chorul’ po-lu-'os-trov 'cho-rul) is the predominantly ice-covered 5.6 km wide peninsula projecting from Graham Coast, [MASK] Peninsula 5.6 km westwards into Beascochea Bay, and ending in Holst Point.

Misty Pass (63°29′S57°59′W﻿ / ﻿63.483°S 57.983°W) is a pass, 700 metres (2,300 ft) high, between the head of Broad Valley and Ogoya Glacier descending north to Bransfield Strait, situated 8 nautical miles (15 km) southeast of Cape Ducorps on Trinity Peninsula, [MASK].

Marescot Point (63°29′S58°35′W﻿ / ﻿63.483°S 58.583°W) is a small but distinctive low rocky point projecting north from Trinity Peninsula, [MASK], 2.5 nautical miles (5 km) east of Thanaron Point.

The Hennessy Islands (65°53′S65°43′W﻿ / ﻿65.883°S 65.717°W) are a group of small islands 2 nautical miles (4 km) in extent, lying 4 nautical miles (7 km) southeast of Jurva Point, the southeast end of Renaud Island, in the Biscoe Islands of [MASK].

Ribnik Island (Bulgarian: остров Рибник, ‘Ostrov Ribnik’ 'os-trov 'rib-nik) is a mostly ice-covered island in the Pitt group of Biscoe Islands, [MASK].

Mraka Sound (Bulgarian: залив Мрака, ‘Zaliv Mraka’ 'za-liv 'mra-ka) is a roughly rectangular water body extending 5 km in southeast-northwest direction and 4.2 km in southwest-northeast direction in Biscoe Islands, [MASK].

Vanand Peak (Bulgarian: връх Вананд, ‘Vrah Vanand’ 'vr&h va-'nand) is the sharp peak rising to 3100 m in Zinsmeister Ridge on the northeast side of Vinson Massif in Sentinel Range, Ellsworth Mountains in [MASK], and surmounting Dater Glacier to the east and its tributary Hinkley Glacier to the northwest.

Hinkley Glacier (78°27′S85°20′W﻿ / ﻿78.450°S 85.333°W) is a glacier flowing northeastward from Corbet Peak and Schoening Peak, Vinson Massif on the east slope of Sentinel Range in the Ellsworth Mountains, [MASK], and continuing between Mount Segers and Zinsmeister Ridge to enter Dater Glacier southeast of Nebeska Peak and northwest of Sipey Peak.

Hinkley Glacier (78°27′S85°20′W﻿ / ﻿78.450°S 85.333°W) is a glacier flowing northeastward from Corbet Peak and Schoening Peak, Vinson Massif on the east slope of Sentinel Range in the Ellsworth Mountains, [MASK], and continuing between Mount Segers and Zinsmeister Ridge to enter Dater Glacier southeast of Nebeska Peak and northwest of Sipey Peak.

Eliason Glacier (64°15′S59°25′W﻿ / ﻿64.250°S 59.417°W) is a glacier 5 nautical miles (9 km) long close west of Mount Hornsby, flowing south from Detroit Plateau into the ice piedmont north of Larsen Inlet, Nordenskjöld Coast in northern Graham Land, [MASK].
Mount Hornsby (64°11′49″S59°20′43″W﻿ / ﻿64.19694°S 59.34528°W) is a prominent snow-capped mountain on the south side of the middle reaches of Sjogren Glacier, Trinity Peninsula, [MASK].

Kaloyan Nunatak rises to approximately 400 m in Delchev Ridge, Tangra Mountains, on eastern Livingston Island in the South Shetland Islands, [MASK].

Amphibole Peak (84°44′S173°26′W﻿ / ﻿84.733°S 173.433°W) is, at 1,660 metres (5,450 ft), the highest peak in the Gabbro Hills, standing 4 nautical miles (7 km) north of Mount Llano, in the Queen Maud Mountains of [MASK].

Mount Justman (84°35′S172°56′W﻿ / ﻿84.583°S 172.933°W) is a mountain 740 metres (2,430 ft) high along the edge of the Ross Ice Shelf in [MASK], standing in the northern part of the Gabbro Hills, midway between Olliver Peak and Mount Roth.

Aldridge Peak (72°27′S167°24′E﻿ / ﻿72.450°S 167.400°E) is a 2,290-metre (7,510 ft) peak on the ridge between Hearfield Glacier and Trafalgar Glacier in the Victory Mountains, situated on the Borchgrevink Coast, named for Anglo-Norwegian explorer Carsten Borchgrevink (1864–1934), Victoria Land, [MASK].

Conard Peak (72°22′S167°26′E﻿ / ﻿72.367°S 167.433°E) is a peak, 2,230 metres (7,320 ft) high, along the north side of Hearfield Glacier, about 5 nautical miles (9 km) north of Aldridge Peak, in the Cartographers Range, Victory Mountains, in Victoria Land, [MASK].

Jutland Glacier (71°55′S166°12′E﻿ / ﻿71.917°S 166.200°E) is a broad tributary glacier, 15 nautical miles (28 km) long and 4 nautical miles (7.4 km) wide, in the Victory Mountains of Victoria Land, [MASK].

Mount Jennings (72°32′S166°15′E﻿ / ﻿72.533°S 166.250°E) is a peak rising to about 2,800 metres (9,200 ft) immediately south of Mount Roy in the Barker Range of the Victory Mountains, in Victoria Land, [MASK].
Kyle Peak is a peak 2 nautical miles (4 km) northeast of Mount McCarthy, rising to about 2,850 metres (9,350 ft) in the Barker Range of the Victory Mountains, Victoria Land, [MASK].

Mount Frosch is a mainly snow-covered mountain, 2,750 metres (9,020 ft) high, standing 3 nautical miles (6 km) northeast of Mount Riddolls at the head of Borchgrevink Glacier, in the Victory Mountains of Victoria Land, [MASK].

Gruendler Glacier (72°38′S167°28′E﻿ / ﻿72.633°S 167.467°E) is a tributary glacier that drains the northern slopes of the Malta Plateau near Mount Hussey and flows north into Trainer Glacier, in the Victory Mountains of Victoria Land, [MASK].
Named by New Zealand Geological Survey [MASK] Expedition (NZGSAE), 1957–58, in association with the Victory Mountains and after the famous British naval victory of 1805.

Mount Finch (72°34′S167°23′E﻿ / ﻿72.567°S 167.383°E) is a mountain, 2,100 metres (6,900 ft) high, standing at the west side of the mouth of Trainer Glacier where the latter enters Trafalgar Glacier, in the Victory Mountains of Victoria Land, [MASK].

Montecchi Glacier (72°4′S167°35′E﻿ / ﻿72.067°S 167.583°E) is a tributary glacier that drains east from Bertalan Peak to enter Tucker Glacier just north of Mount Hazlett, in the Victory Mountains of Victoria Land, [MASK].

The Monteath Hills (72°6′S166°30′E﻿ / ﻿72.100°S 166.500°E) are a group of mountains in the Victory Mountains of Victoria Land, [MASK], bounded by Jutland Glacier, Midway Glacier, Pearl Harbor Glacier, and Plata Glacier.

Mount Freeman (72°43′S168°21′E﻿ / ﻿72.717°S 168.350°E) is a prominent mountain, 2,880 metres (9,450 ft) high, surmounting the base of Walker Ridge, 2 nautical miles (4 km) northwest of Mount Lepanto, in the Victory Mountains of Victoria Land, [MASK].

Midway Glacier (72°10′S166°50′E﻿ / ﻿72.167°S 166.833°E) is a tributary glacier that flows south along the west side of Evans Ridge into Pearl Harbor Glacier, in the Victory Mountains of Victoria Land, [MASK].

Handler Ridge (72°30′S167°0′E﻿ / ﻿72.500°S 167.000°E) is a prominent ridge about 10 nautical miles (20 km) long which serves as a divide between Croll Glacier and the upper portion of Trafalgar Glacier, in the Victory Mountains of Victoria Land, [MASK].

Mount Hancox (72°38′S166°59′E﻿ / ﻿72.633°S 166.983°E) is a prominent mountain, 3,245 metres (10,650 ft) high, about 6 nautical miles (11 km) southeast of Mount Burton, rising above the north margin of Malta Plateau in the Victory Mountains of Victoria Land, [MASK].

Mount Harrington (72°45′S168°57′E﻿ / ﻿72.750°S 168.950°E) is one of the highest peaks in the east end of the Victory Mountains, Victoria Land, [MASK], rising to 2,610 metres (8,560 ft) on the west side of Whitehall Glacier and 5 nautical miles (9 km) southwest of Mount Northampton.

Mount Lopatin (72°51′S168°4′E﻿ / ﻿72.850°S 168.067°E) is a mountain, 2,670 metres (8,760 ft) high, situated 6 nautical miles (11 km) east-southeast of Mount Riddolls in the Victory Mountains of Victoria Land, [MASK].

Harrison Peak (72°24′S166°39′E﻿ / ﻿72.400°S 166.650°E) is a peak 2,830 metres (9,280 ft) high along the north side of Wood Glacier, about 5 nautical miles (9 km) north of Mount McDonald, in the Victory Mountains of Victoria Land, [MASK].

Mount McDonald (72°30′S166°36′E﻿ / ﻿72.500°S 166.600°E) is a peak rising to 2,470 metres (8,100 ft) on the north side of Trafalgar Glacier, 4 nautical miles (7 km) northwest of Mount Burton, in the Victory Mountains of Victoria Land, [MASK].
McElroy Ridge (72°37′S168°3′E﻿ / ﻿72.617°S 168.050°E) is a high mountainous ridge, 16 nautical miles (30 km) long, in the Victory Mountains of Victoria Land, [MASK].
McKellar Glacier is a tributary glacier flowing south along the east side of Evans Ridge into Pearl Harbor Glacier in the Victory Mountains of Victoria Land, [MASK].

Hearfield Glacier (72°26′S167°42′E﻿ / ﻿72.433°S 167.700°E) is a tributary glacier which flows east-southeast along the south side of the Cartographers Range and enters Trafalgar Glacier just east of Aldridge Peak, in the Victory Mountains of Victoria Land, [MASK].

Mount Hazlett (72°6′S167°35′E﻿ / ﻿72.100°S 167.583°E) is a mountain, 2,080 metres (6,820 ft) high, at the south side of the mouth of Montecchi Glacier where the latter enters Tucker Glacier, in the Victory Mountains of Victoria Land, [MASK].

Mount Hussey (72°46′S167°31′E﻿ / ﻿72.767°S 167.517°E) is a mountain 2,790 metres (9,150 ft) high, rising from the spur at the head of Gruendler Glacier, in the Victory Mountains of Victoria Land, [MASK].
Malta Plateau (72°58′S167°18′E﻿ / ﻿72.967°S 167.300°E) is an ice-covered plateau of about 25 nautical miles (46 km) extent in the Victory Mountains of Victoria Land, [MASK].
It was named by the New Zealand [MASK] Place-Names Committee to commemorate the island of Malta in association with the Victory Mountains.
Mount Holdsworth (72°8′S166°35′E﻿ / ﻿72.133°S 166.583°E) is a granite peak, 2,360 metres (7,740 ft) high, in the eastern part of the Monteath Hills, in the Victory Mountains of Victoria Land, [MASK].

Latino Peak (72°9′S167°33′E﻿ / ﻿72.150°S 167.550°E) is peak 2,290 metres (7,500 ft) high situated 4 nautical miles (7 km) south-southwest of Mount Hazlett in the Victory Mountains of Victoria Land, [MASK].

Lensen Glacier (72°18′S166°48′E﻿ / ﻿72.300°S 166.800°E) is a tributary glacier that flows northeast to enter Pearl Harbor Glacier just east of Mount Pearson, in the Victory Mountains of Victoria Land, [MASK].

Mount Lepanto (72°44′S168°27′E﻿ / ﻿72.733°S 168.450°E) is a major peak, 2,910 metres (9,550 ft) high, situated 2 nautical miles (4 km) southeast of Mount Freeman in the Victory Mountains of Victoria Land, [MASK].
Martin Hill is a conspicuous ice-free hill at the west side of Whitehall Glacier in the Victory Mountains of Victoria Land, [MASK].

The Victory Mountains (72°40′S168°00′E﻿ / ﻿72.667°S 168.000°E) is a major group of mountains in Victoria Land, [MASK], about 160 kilometres (99 mi) long and 80 km (50 mi) wide, which is bounded primarily by Mariner and Tucker glaciers and the Ross Sea.

The Victory Mountains (72°40′S168°00′E﻿ / ﻿72.667°S 168.000°E) is a major group of mountains in Victoria Land, [MASK], about 160 kilometres (99 mi) long and 80 km (50 mi) wide, which is bounded primarily by Mariner and Tucker glaciers and the Ross Sea.
The Millen Range (72°20′S166°15′E﻿ / ﻿72.333°S 166.250°E) is a prominent northwest–southeast trending mountain range, located west of the Cartographers Range in the Victory Mountains of [MASK].
Cartographers Range (72°21′S167°50′E﻿ / ﻿72.350°S 167.833°E) is a rugged mountain range about 40 km (25 mi) long in the Victory Mountains, Victoria Land in [MASK].

Yashwant Singh Parmar University of Horticulture and Forestry in district Solan, Himachal Pradesh, India is the first university of its kind in [MASK] with an exclusive mandate of education, research and extension in horticulture and forestry.
The Fish Islands (66°2′S65°25′W﻿ / ﻿66.033°S 65.417°W) are a group of small islands lying in the northern part of the entrance to Holtedahl Bay, off the west coast of Graham Land, [MASK].
The Fish Islands (66°2′S65°25′W﻿ / ﻿66.033°S 65.417°W) are a group of small islands lying in the northern part of the entrance to Holtedahl Bay, off the west coast of Graham Land, [MASK].
Flounder Island (66°1′S65°24′W﻿ / ﻿66.017°S 65.400°W) is the largest of the Fish Islands at the north side of Holtedahl Bay, off the west coast of Graham Land, [MASK].
It was charted by the British Graham Land Expedition under John Rymill, 1934–37, and so named by the UK [MASK] Place-Names Committee in 1959 after the flounder, in association with the Fish Islands.
The Minnows (66°1′S65°23′W﻿ / ﻿66.017°S 65.383°W) are a group of small islands and rocks lying east of Flounder Island in the Fish Islands, off the west coast of Graham Land, [MASK].

They were charted by the British Graham Land Expedition under John Rymill, 1934–37, and were so named by the UK [MASK] Place-Names Committee in 1959 because the group lies in the Fish Islands, and "minnow" is a term for a small fish.
Mackerel Island (66°1′S65°26′W﻿ / ﻿66.017°S 65.433°W) is an island immediately west of Flounder Island in the Fish Islands, off the west coast of Graham Land, [MASK].
It was charted by the British Graham Land Expedition under John Rymill, 1934–37, and was so named by the UK [MASK] Place-Names Committee in 1959 after the mackerel as it is one of the Fish Islands.
